newsitem.title: USA: U.S. touts economic benefits of NATO expansion.
newsitem.headline: U.S. touts economic benefits of NATO expansion.

text.p: The Clinton administration on Tuesday touted the economic benefits of NATO enlargement, saying that it would promote economic reform and investment in Eastern Europe and help spur U.S. exports.
"The security and economic dimension really mesh and go hand-in-hand," U.S. Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs Stuart Eizenstat told reporters.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation last week invited three former Soviet bloc states -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- to join the military alliance.

Lawmakers in the U.S. Senate, which must ratify the expansion, have raised questions about the planned enlargement, including whether it is necessary and how much it will cost. A Senate vote is not expected until next year.
State Department officials, who declined to be named, said it was too early to say how much opposition NATO expansion would run into in the Senate.
But they said it was not too early for the administration to start making the case for the move, and Tuesday's briefing on the economic benefits of a larger NATO was part of that.

Eizenstat said central European countries had the fastest growing economies in Europe, with a big appetite for consumer durable goods and huge infrastructure needs, especially in telecommunications and environmental clean-up.
He acknowledged that NATO expansion would also provide U.S. defence contractors with added sales oppurtunities, but he played down the economic significance of that.
"We've encouraged them (the prospective new NATO members) not to make big-ticket purchases like fighter aircraft," because that could overburden their economies and their budgets, Eizenstat said.
He also said he would like to see the United States do more to help central European countries by lowering import tariffs.
But he admitted that would likely require legislation and that there were no plans to do that now.
